commander.name: Major-General John Nichols
commander.previous_service: Appointed by Montgomery. Led division at El Alamein, Mareth Line, and Wadi Akarit. Commanded through Tunisia victory.

tanks.note: Infantry division - no organic tanks. Supported by 3rd County of London Yeomanry (Valentine tanks) at Wadi Akarit.

artillery.note: Full divisional artillery. 17-pounder AT guns proved highly effective at Wadi Akarit.

soft_skin_vehicles.note: Standard British infantry division motor transport allocation. Vehicles refitted during Alexandria rest period.

supply_logistics.supply_status: EXCELLENT - Division withdrawn from combat 19 April after Wadi Akarit. Ordered to Alexandria 24 April for rest and refit. Tunisia Campaign ended 13 May with Axis surrender. May-June spent in Egypt refitting, receiving replacements, and training for Operation Husky (Sicily). Full resupply of ammunition, fuel, vehicles, and equipment during rest period.
notes: Wadi Akarit battle 5-6 April - light casualties (69th Brigade assault)

subordinate_units.note: Led assault at Wadi Akarit 5-6 April. Attacked between 4th Indian Division and Djebel Roumana. Seized Point 85, crossed anti-tank ditch under fire. Light casualties compared to Mareth. Brigade sent forward 2 April with divisional machine gunners and 3rd County of London Yeomanry tanks.
Reserve brigade at Wadi Akarit. Previously led Mareth assault (heavy casualties March). Refitting during April-June rest period.
Reserve brigade. Refitting and training for Sicily operations during May-June.

tactical_doctrine.role: Q2 1943 divides into two phases: (1) Final Tunisia offensive - Wadi Akarit assault 5-6 April, where 69th Brigade attacked central sector between 4th Indian Division and 51st Highland Division, breaching anti-tank ditch and securing objectives with light casualties. (2) Post-Tunisia rest and refit - withdrawn 19 April, moved to Alexandria 24 April. After Axis surrender 13 May, division spent May-June refitting, receiving replacements, and training for Operation Husky (Sicily invasion).
special_capabilities: Battle-hardened veteran division - continuous combat Nov 1942 to April 1943
Successful assault operations at Wadi Akarit (light casualties)
Combined arms coordination with supporting armor
known_issues: Division fatigued after 6 months continuous combat (Nov 1942-April 1943)
Transitioning from desert to amphibious operations (Sicily)
Training needed for beach assault tactics

historical_context.operational_status: Active - Final Tunisia battles, then rest/refit for Sicily
major_battles: Battle of Wadi Akarit (5-6 April 1943): 69th Brigade led assault in central sector between 4th Indian Division and Djebel Roumana. Crossed anti-tank ditch under fire, secured objectives. Light casualties. Contributed to Axis withdrawal and final collapse of Tunisia defenses.
Tunisia Campaign conclusion (to 13 May 1943): 250,000 Axis prisoners. Eighth Army victory.
Rest and refit period (19 April - June 1943): Withdrawn to Alexandria. Refitting, replacements, training for Sicily invasion.
notes: Q2 1943 split between combat (April) and rest/refit (May-June)
